items.title: Bridgewater's flagship Pure Alpha surges 33% in 2025, outperforming biggest hedge fund peers
items.author: Anirban Sen
items.summary:
- Bridgewater's flagship Pure Alpha gained about 33% YTD through Dec. 29, outpacing the S&P 500's ~17% rise in 2025, as macro funds posted record profits.
- Other Bridgewater funds posted solid gains: All Weather +20.4%, Asia Total Return +36.9%, China Total Return +34.2%, and AIA Macro +11.9%, with AUM around $92B as of Sept. 30.
- The firm has pushed AI investing (a $5B AI fund, an ETF with State Street, Artificial Investor tool) as founder Dalio exited; leadership changes underway.

items.title: Brookfield to start cloud business amid AI frenzy, The Information reports
items.author: Reuters
items.summary:
- Brookfield launches Radiant, a cloud unit to lease AI chips to developers, aiming end-to-end control of the AI stack and tying Radiant to a $10B Brookfield AI fund with priority data-center access.
- Plans include France, Qatar and Sweden, after a $100B AI infrastructure push anchored by Brookfield's AI Infrastructure Fund with about half of its $10B commitments from Nvidia and the Kuwait Investment Authority.
- The strategy targets AI capex and energy bottlenecks by owning inputs to the stack, potentially pressuring Amazon, Microsoft and Oracle on capital efficiency.

items.title: Trump Media unveils plan to distribute new cryptocurrency to shareholders
items.author: Manya Saini
items.summary:
- Trump Media and Technology Group will distribute a new digital token to shareholders—one token per share—with a 2026 launch planned on the Cronos blockchain.
- The plan deepens the Trump family's push into digital assets as crypto policy shows greater support, despite potential conflicts of interest scrutiny.
- This follows prior crypto activity by the family, including the $TRUMP meme coin and ventures like World Liberty Financial, amid a broader crypto downturn.

items.title: TSX poised for biggest annual gain in over 15 years despite year-end retreat
items.author: Avinash P
items.summary: - Canada's S&P/TSX Composite fell 0.4% to 31,712.76 on the final trading day of 2025, extending a four-session slide. - Despite the retreat, the index rose about 29% in 2025, its best annual gain since 2009, led by gold, silver and strength in financials. - Analysts warn momentum could fade if commodity cycles weaken; 2026 may see more modest gains as materials and metals rally proves unsustainable.

items.title: Silver shines in 2025 global market spotlight as softs, oil lag
items.author: Naveen Thukral, Lucas Liew
items.summary:
- Silver rose about 161% to clear $80/oz as safe-haven demand supported prices.
- Copper near all-time highs at about $12,960/tonne; gold up ~66% as AI/renewables demand and a softer dollar buoy metals.
- Oil down ~15%; cocoa -48%; sugar and Robusta coffee about -20% as ample supplies weigh on soft commodities; metals may rise if rates fall in 2026.

items.title: Korea Zinc revises share issuance for US smelter to $1.94 billion
items.author: Reuters
items.summary: - Korea Zinc revised its planned share issuance to 2.833 trillion won ($1.94 billion) from 2.85 trillion won, citing the finalized issuance price per share and currency movements.\n- Funds will finance a non-ferrous metal smelter in Tennessee to produce core minerals such as antimony and gallium.\n- The project aims to help the United States reduce dependence on China for materials critical to electronics and weapons manufacturing.

items.title: Disney agrees to pay $10 million to resolve alleged violations of child privacy laws, Justice Dept says
items.author: Reuters
items.summary:
- DOJ says Disney will pay $10M to settle COPPA violations tied to certain YouTube videos and implement a COPPA-compliant program for YouTube going forward.
- The complaint alleges some videos were not labeled as Made for Kids, allowing collection of data from children under 13 for targeted ads.
- The FTC referred the case to DOJ; AAG Brett Shumate emphasized parental input; Disney did not comment; concerns Disney's YouTube uploads.

items.title: India imposes three-year tariff on some steel products to curb cheap imports
items.author: Reuters
items.summary: - India imposes a three-year safeguard duty on selected steel products to curb cheap imports.\n- Duties run 12% in year 1, 11.5% in year 2, and 11% in year 3; excludes some developing countries and stainless steel.\n- The move follows a 200-day 12% temporary tariff and aims to shield domestic steel producers amid global trade frictions.
